Award.AwardTitle: Chemistry Communication Institute: A Pilot Program; September 2009, Seattle, WA
Award.AbstractNarration:
This pilot project will investigate new strategies to enhance the preparation of chemistry professionals to communicate with broader audiences. The overall goal is to cultivate a cadre of chemistry communication leaders who can 1) help bring about a cultural change in the field of chemistry to value and reward public communication; 2) serve as mentors and ambassadors for chemistry communication efforts; and 3) share a modular chemistry communication curriculum/resource guide.

This project will generate new knowledge about strategies to enhance the preparation of informal science educators with particular attention to the following central questions: 1) to what extent does this course improve chemists' ability to communicate their own research to broader audiences; 2) how does the role-playing experience of being a journalist for a few days affect the preparation of chemists to serve as sources for journalists; 3) how does this preparation affect, if at all, chemists' understanding of and attitudes toward the process of public communication of chemistry; and 4) how does the course affect participants' ideas, attitudes, plans, and actions with respect to undertaking communication efforts in their home departments? These questions will be addressed by means of pre- and post-course writing assignments, pre- and post-questionnaires, and follow-up surveys and email/phone interaction with participants.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project supports the goals of the International Year of Chemistry in 2011 and responds to a call for chemists to become more involved with public communication about chemistry. The project conducted a pilot test of an intensive training experience in chemistry communication techniques to 15 postdoctoral researchers. Participants took back to their home institutions a curriculum and resource book that would support them in sharing the information with others. These findings have demonstrated the transformative potential of this week-long institute to enhance the preparation and leadership skills of chemists to engage in public communication.

            The pilot results found a low level of prior knowledge about the science communication process among chemistry postdocs. Furthermore, results showed that a 1-week training course of this nature could prepare them to successfully engage in a wide range of communication  activities, including freelance writing projects. Already, a large number of secondary school and general public audiences have benefited from the many communication and outreach efforts that were spurred by this project, including several large-scale television and webcasting events. A conservative estimate is some 260,000 people or more have indirectly benefited through the efforts of the postdoc participants.

            With supplemental funding, the PI was able to work with researchers at 17 active NSF Science and Technology Centers to develop content for broader audiences highlighting the research at these centers and the role of team science in tackling these research problems. This process helped to give researchers a better understanding of how to structure content for general audiences about their specialties. The materials were published in a booklet entitled Profiles in Team Science 2012 Edition, disseminated nationally to center visitors, sponsors, community members, prospective students and collaborators, policy leaders, journalists, and others.

            The supplemental project has helped to highlight how chemistry is at once a central science and a 'decentralized' one, given its intersection with so many other areas of science and engineering as exemplified by the current NSF STCs. The work has helped the chemistry communities involved in the STCs highlight for the public the role of chemistry in team science. This project contributes toward informing and preparing the chemistry workforce of the future to function in the interdisciplinary landscape, and it will help equip chemists in those STCS with enhanced strategies to communicate about their NSF funded research with broader audiences.

            These findings contribute new knowledge to the science communication field in addition to chemistry outreach. My published research previously funded by the NSF chemistry division has demonstrated that the roles and contributions of the chemical and related disciplines in multidisciplinary teams are not readily apparent in media reports. This effort has equipped researchers to interact with journalists, and it is producing communication products that will foster a greater understanding among journalists, policymakers, and the general public about NSF funded research, the chemical disciplines, and the role of chemistry in tackling some of the toughest multidisciplinary problems facing society now and in the future.
